title: 114_s2182
content:
The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include spending limits. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" sets spending limits for fiscal year 2016 in the House of Representatives and the Senate to prevent exceeding specified budget authority and outlays. Adjustments can be made for bills related to the global war on terrorism. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" sets spending limits for fiscal year 2016 in the House of Representatives and the Senate to prevent exceeding specified budget authority and outlays. Adjustments can be made for bills related to the global war on terrorism, allowing the chair of the House or Senate Committee on the Budget to adjust spending limits for congressional enforcement and budgetary aggregates. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" establishes spending limits for fiscal year 2016 in Congress, allowing adjustments for bills related to the global war on terrorism. The House or Senate Committee on Appropriations may revise suballocations accordingly. The House or Senate Committee on Appropriations may report revised suballocations for fiscal year 2016 appropriations related to the Global War on Terrorism. Adjustments are allowed for bills designating amounts for Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terrorism. For fiscal year 2016, adjustments for Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terrorism shall not exceed $58 billion in budget authority and outlays. SEC. 317. CERTAIN SPENDING LIMITS. The House of Representatives and Senate cannot consider any bill that would exceed specified spending limits, except for certain exempt functions like Social Security, Medicare, Veterans Benefits, Net Interest, and Military personnel accounts. SEC. 102. STATUTORY ENFORCEMENT OF SPENDING CAPS THROUGH SEQUESTRATION. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section 318 for enforcing discretionary and direct spending caps. Implementation of sequesters includes discretionary spending limits under section 316 and direct spending enforcement under section 254 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Sequestration for direct spending enforcement shall be implemented under section 254 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Certain payments are exempt from sequestration, including military personnel accounts, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, net interest, and discretionary appropriations. Certain payments such as military retirement, Social Security, veterans, net interest, and discretionary appropriations are exempt from sequestration. The provisions of section 258A of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 shall apply to the consideration in the House of Representatives and the Senate. Under subsection (a) and section 319(c), the provisions of section 258A of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 shall apply to the consideration in the House of Representatives and the Senate of a bill or joint resolution to override the order if the bill or joint resolution achieves the same level of reductions in new budget authority and outlays for the applicable fiscal year as set forth in the order. It is not in order to consider a bill or joint resolution in the House of Representatives or Senate that waives, modifies, or alters the order. In the House or Senate, a bill or joint resolution cannot be considered if it waives, modifies, or alters a sequestration order unless it achieves the same reductions in new budget authority and outlays for the applicable fiscal year as specified in the order. TITLE II--CAP

SEC. 201. LIMIT ON TOTAL SPENDING. Section 250(c) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to redefine the term 'GDP' as the gross domestic product consistent with Department of Commerce definitions. Additionally, Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section after section 318. "SEC. 319. ENFORCING GDP OUTLAY LIMITS." The term 'GDP outlay limit' refers to an amount calculated by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget based on projected GDP for each fiscal year, with specific percentages set for fiscal years 2016 to 2022. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget establishes GDP outlay limits for each fiscal year, with specific percentages set for fiscal years 2019 to 2025. Total federal outlays are determined based on these limits. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget establishes GDP outlay limits for each fiscal year. Total federal outlays include all on-budget and off-budget expenditures. Sequestration to enforce these limits is implemented according to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Exempt programs are not subject to these limits. Sequestration limits are set by the Office of Management and Budget based on GDP outlays for each fiscal year. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 enforces these limits, exempting certain programs like military personnel, TRICARE, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, and net interest payments. SEC. 320. ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 includes new enforcement measures. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include new enforcement procedures that prevent exceeding current GDP outlay limits. TITLE III--BALANCE

Sec. 301. Requirement for a balanced budget amendment to be submitted to states. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot use additional borrowing authority until the Archivist of the United States sends a balanced budget amendment to the States. This amendment must limit total outlays to not exceed total receipts, set a spending cap as a percentage of GDP, and mandate that tax increases require a 2/3 vote in Congress for approval. It is not allowed in the House or Senate to consider any bill or joint resolution that does not comply with these requirements. The balanced budget amendment mandates limiting total outlays, setting a spending cap, and requiring a 2/3 vote in Congress for tax increases. It prohibits the Secretary of the Treasury from additional borrowing until the Archivist of the United States transmits the amendment to the States. Bills not meeting these requirements cannot be considered in the House or Senate.
